Instrument.description: Wind section notated on a grand staff.
Piccolo in E♭, sounding a minor third above the standard piccolo.
Piccolo in D♭, sounding a semitone above the standard piccolo.
Flute in G, sounding a fifth higher than the standard flute.
Notched, end-blown vertical bamboo flute used in Korean folk music.
Flute in E♭, sounding a minor third above the standard flute.
Flute in G, sounding a fourth lower than the standard flute.
Flute in C, sounding an octave lower than the standard flute.
Flute in G, sounding an octave below the alto flute.
Flute in C, sounding two octaves lower than the standard flute.
Flute in G, sounding two octaves below the alto flute.
Flute in C, sounding three octaves below the standard flute.
Flute in C, sounding four octaves below the standard flute.
Chinese bamboo transverse flute, pitched in A.
Chinese bamboo transverse flute, pitched in G. The most common variant.
Chinese bamboo transverse flute, pitched in F.
Chinese bamboo transverse flute, pitched in E.
Chinese bamboo transverse flute, pitched in D.
Chinese bamboo transverse flute, pitched in C.
Fife pitched in B♭ (when all 6 holes are covered), notated in A♭, sounding a minor sixth higher than written.
Whistle pitched in D (notated at concert pitch).
Whistle pitched in B♭ (notated at concert pitch).
The smallest modern recorder, pitched in C (an octave above the soprano).
The second smallest recorder, pitched in F (an octave above the alto).
Also known as the descant recorder. Pitched in C.
Soprano or descant recorder, pitched in C.
Also known as the treble recorder. Pitched in F. Sometimes with an extra key for low E.
Recorder pitched in C (an octave below the soprano).
Recorder pitched in F (an octave below the alto).
Recorder pitched in C (an octave below the tenor).
Recorder pitched in F (an octave below the bass).
Alto (sometimes called tenor) ocarina in C.
Alto (sometimes called tenor) ocarina in B♭.
Alto (sometimes called tenor) ocarina in G.
Alto (sometimes called tenor) ocarina in F.
Soprano ocarina made from an animal horn. Pitched in C.
Soprano ocarina made from an animal horn. Pitched in C.
Alto ocarina made from an animal horn. Pitched in F.
Tenor ocarina made from an animal horn. Pitched in C (an octave below the soprano).
Bass ocarina made from an animal horn. Pitched in F (an octave below the alto).
End-blown flute made of a row of closed tubes.
South American traditional flute pitched in C.
South American traditional flute pitched in C.
South American traditional flute pitched in G. The most common variant.
South American traditional flute pitched in F.
South American traditional flute pitched in D.
Very rare variant of the heckelphone in F, sounding a fourth higher than the oboe.
Oboe in E♭, sounding a minor third above the standard oboe. Historically called the oboe musette.
Baroque oboe with three keys, generally made of boxwood.
Oboe in A, sounding a minor third below the standard oboe.
Oboe in F, sounding a perfect fifth below the standard oboe.
Oboe in F, sounding a perfect fifth below the standard oboe.
Oboe in C, sounding an octave lower than the standard oboe. Similar, but not identical to, the heckelphone.
Oboe in C, sounding an octave lower than the standard oboe. Similar, but not identical to, the bass oboe.
Very rare instrument similar to the heckelphone, with slightly smaller bore and lower range.
12th-century conical bore, double-reed instrument, pitched in F (an octave above the alto shawm).
12th-century conical bore, double-reed instrument, pitched in C.
12th-century conical bore, double-reed instrument, pitched in F (a fifth below the soprano shawm).
12th-century conical bore, double-reed instrument, pitched in C (an octave below the soprano shawm).
12th-century conical bore, double-reed instrument, pitched in F (an octave below the alto shawm).
12th-century conical bore, double-reed instrument, pitched in C (an octave below the tenor shawm).
French baroque reed instrument of uncertain identity. Not to be confused with the crumhorn.
Renaissance double-reed instrument with curved end, pitched in C.
Renaissance double-reed instrument with curved end, pitched in C.
Renaissance double-reed instrument with curved end, pitched in F (a fifth below the soprano crumhorn).
Renaissance double-reed instrument with curved end, pitched in C (an octave below the soprano crumhorn).
Renaissance double-reed instrument with curved end, pitched in F (an octave below the alto crumhorn).
Renaissance double-reed instrument with curved end, pitched in C (an octave below the tenor crumhorn).
Renaissance double-reed instrument with straight end and single bore, pitched in C.
Renaissance double-reed instrument with straight end and single bore, pitched in C.
Renaissance double-reed instrument with straight end and single bore, pitched in G (a fourth below the soprano cornamuse).
Renaissance double-reed instrument with straight end and single bore, pitched in C (an octave below the soprano cornamuse).
Renaissance double-reed instrument with straight end and single bore, pitched in F (a ninth below the alto cornamuse).
20th-century instrument similar to the crumhorn and cornamuse, pitched in C.
20th-century instrument similar to the crumhorn and cornamuse, pitched in F (a fifth below the soprano kelhorn).
20th-century instrument similar to the crumhorn and cornamuse, pitched in C (an octave below the soprano kelhorn).
20th-century instrument similar to the crumhorn and cornamuse, pitched in F (an octave below the alto kelhorn).
20th-century instrument similar to the crumhorn and cornamuse, pitched in C (an octave below the tenor kelhorn).
16th-century double-reed instrument with a conical bore, pitched in F (a fourth higher than the soprano rauschpfeife).
16th-century double-reed instrument with a conical bore, pitched in C.
16th-century double-reed instrument with a conical bore, pitched in C.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in F.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in E.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in D.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in C.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in B.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in B♭.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in A.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in A.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in G.
Armenian double-reed instrument made of apricot wood, pitched in A (an octave below the normal duduk in A).
Indian double-reed instrument with a flared bell.
Sopranino clarinet (despite the name) in G.
Soprano clarinet in B♭. One of the standard orchestral clarinets.
Soprano clarinet in B♭. One of the standard orchestral clarinets.
Soprano clarinet in A. One of the standard orchestral clarinets.
Similar to the standard soprano clarinet, but with an extension to the lower range.
Member of the clarinet family with a larger bore and extended lower range.
Bass clarinet in B♭. An octave lower than the B♭ soprano clarinet.
Bass clarinet in B♭. An octave lower than the B♭ soprano clarinet. Notated in the treble clef (‘French notation’).
Bass clarinet in B♭. An octave lower than the B♭ soprano clarinet. Notated in the bass clef (‘German notation’).
Bass clarinet in A. Extremely rare and almost never used today. Notated in the treble clef (‘French notation’).
Bass clarinet in A. Extremely rare and almost never used today. Notated in the bass clef (‘German notation’).
Contra-alto clarinet in E♭. An octave lower than the E♭ alto clarinet.
Contrabass clarinet in B♭. An octave lower than the B♭ bass clarinet.
Predecessor of the modern-day clarinet, pitched in F (an octave above the alto chalumeau).
Predecessor of the modern-day clarinet, pitched in C (an octave above the tenor chalumeau).
Predecessor of the modern-day clarinet, pitched in F (a fourth above the tenor chalumeau).
Predecessor of the modern-day clarinet, pitched in C.
Predecessor of the modern-day clarinet, pitched in C (an octave below the soprano chalumeau).
Predecessor of the modern-day clarinet, pitched in F (an fifth below the tenor chalumeau).
Keyless single-reed instrument with a cylindrical bore and slightly flared bell, in D.
Keyless single-reed instrument with a cylindrical bore and slightly flared bell, in C.
Keyless single-reed instrument with a cylindrical bore and slightly flared bell, in B♭.
Keyless single-reed instrument with a cylindrical bore and slightly flared bell, in G.
Single-reed, conical bore instrument used in Hungarian and Romanian folk music.
Very rare single-reed, conical bore woodwind instrument.
Saxophone in B♭ (an octave above the soprano).
Saxophone in E♭ (an octave above the alto).
Consists of two soprano saxophones joined together, played either separately or simultaneously.
Saxophone in B♭ (an octave above the tenor).
Saxophone in F (a tone above the alto).
Rare wooden instrument with a wide conical bore, akin to a saxophone.
Saxophone in E♭ (an octave above the baritone).
Saxophone in C (a tone above the tenor).
Saxophone in B♭ (an octave below the soprano).
Saxophone in B♭ (an octave below the soprano).
Saxophone in E♭ (an octave below the alto).
Saxophone in B♭ (an octave below the tenor).
Saxophone in E♭ (an octave below the baritone).
Saxophone in B♭ (an octave below the bass).
Larger version of the bassoon, sounding an octave lower.
Double-reed instrument with an unusually wide conical bore, normally made of metal.
Renaissance double-reed instrument with a folded conical bore.
Renaissance double-reed instrument; a predecessor of the bassoon.
Single- or double-reed metal instrument with a conical bore, in B♭ (an octave above the soprano).
Single- or double-reed metal instrument with a conical bore, in B♭.
Single- or double-reed metal instrument with a conical bore, in B♭.
Single- or double-reed metal instrument with a conical bore, in E♭.
Single- or double-reed metal instrument with a conical bore, in B♭ (an octave below the soprano).
Single- or double-reed metal instrument with a conical bore, in E♭ (an octave below the alto).
Single- or double-reed metal instrument with a conical bore, in B♭ (an octave below the tenor).
Single- or double-reed metal instrument with a conical bore, in E♭ (an octave below the baritone).
Bellows-driven free-reed instrument with a keyboard or buttons on one end, and buttons on the other.
Type of concertina particularly popular in Argentina and Uruguay.
Bellows-driven free-reed instrument with buttons usually on both ends.
10-hole diatonic harmonica pitched in high G.
10-hole diatonic harmonica pitched in low D.
12-hole chromatic tenor harmonica pitched in C.
Mouth-blown free reed instrument with a keyboard.
Brass section notated on a grand staff.
Horn in F. The most common modern orchestral horn.
Horn in low C (notated in bass clef).
Horn used primarily in Vienna for classical orchestral music.
Cornet in B♭. The most common cornet.
Alto horn in F. (Known as ‘tenor horn’ in British English.)
Alto horn in E♭. (Known as ‘tenor horn’ in British English.)
Baritone horn (sometimes just called ‘baritone’). Notated in bass clef, at concert pitch.
Baritone horn (sometimes just called ‘baritone’). Notated in treble clef, often as a transposing instrument.
Central European variant of the baritone horn. Notated in treble clef, often as a transposing instrument.
Central European variant of the baritone horn. Notated in bass clef, at concert pitch.
Valveless cylindrical horn with cupped mouthpiece.
Trumpet in C. Nowadays the most common orchestral trumpet.
Trumpet in B♭. Still the most common trumpet in non-orchestral contexts.
Trumpet in B♭, with the tubing wound into a smaller coil than the standard trumpet.
Trumpet in D, fitted with a slide much like a trombone. A predecessor of the sackbut.
Bass trumpet in C. The most common bass trumpet in use today.
Bass flugelhorn, originally played in polka bands in central Europe.
Small flugelhorn in B♭, played using a deep bowled mouthpiece.
Medieval wind instrument, consisting of a conical wooden pipe covered in leather. The cornettino is the descant of the family.
Medieval wind instrument, consisting of a conical wooden pipe covered in leather. The soprano is the most common cornett.
Medieval wind instrument, consisting of a conical wooden pipe covered in leather. The soprano is the most common cornett.
Medieval wind instrument, consisting of a conical wooden pipe covered in leather.
Medieval wind instrument, consisting of a conical wooden pipe covered in leather.
Descendant of the cornett, and distant ancestor of the tuba.
Soprano trombone (usually pitched in B♭, an octave above the tenor).
Alto trombone (pitched in E♭ or F).
Orchestral trombone (either tenor or bass; this is often not explicitly specified in scores).
Trombone (notated in treble clef as a transposing instrument in B♭).
Instrument with a similar range to the contrabass trombone, most commonly encountered in 19th-century Italian opera scores.
Renaissance and Baroque trombone. A descendant of the slide trumpet.
Renaissance and Baroque trombone. A descendant of the slide trumpet.
Renaissance and Baroque trombone. A descendant of the slide trumpet.
Euphonium (notated in bass clef at concert pitch).
Euphonium (notated in treble clef as a transposing instrument in B♭).
Orchestral tuba (where the exact type is not specified).
Bass tuba in F (notated in bass clef at concert pitch).
Bass tuba in E♭ (notated in bass clef at concert pitch).
Bass tuba in E♭ (notated in bass clef at concert pitch).
Bass tuba in F (notated in bass clef at concert pitch).
Bass tuba in E♭ (notated in treble clef as a transposing instrument).
Contrabass tuba in C (notated in bass clef).
Contrabass tuba in B♭ (notated in bass clef at concert pitch).
Contrabass tuba in B♭ (notated in treble clef as a transposing instrument).
Sousaphone in B♭ (notated in bass clef).
Sousaphone in B♭ (notated in treble clef).
Sousaphone in B♭ (notated in treble clef at concert pitch).
Conch shell, sometimes fitted with a mouthpiece.
Type of conch shell used as a trumpet in Japan, fitted with a bronze or wooden mouthpiece.
Long wooden natural horn with conical bore and wooden cup-shaped mouthpiece, originating in the Alpine regions.
Long Tibetan trumpet used for Buddhist religious purposes.
Typically made from a ram’s horn and used for Jewish religious purposes.
Plastic horn that produces a loud single pitch.
Large pitched orchestral drums, also known as kettle drums. Sometimes fitted with a pedal to allow quick changes of tuning.
Pitched drums that can be tuned quickly by rotating the drumhead.
Constructed from a series of metal tubes arranged in a keyboard configuration.
Steel drums on a grand staff.
Xylophone with an extended range, matching a 5-octave marimba but sounding an octave higher.
Marimba notated on a grand staff.
Marimba notated on a single staff.
Tubular bells (British English), or chimes (American English).
Tuned bells installed in a bell tower and played with a keyboard.
Soprano glockenspiel for the Orff Schulwerk.
Alto glockenspiel for the Orff Schulwerk.
Soprano metallophone for the Orff Schulwerk.
Soprano xylophone for the Orff Schulwerk.
Generic metallophone for the Orff Schulwerk.
Alto metallophone for the Orff Schulwerk.
Alto xylophone for the Orff Schulwerk.
Bass metallophone for the Orff Schulwerk.
Bass xylophone for the Orff Schulwerk.
Musical saw, played with a violin or cello bow.
Wine glasses played by running moistened fingers around the rim. Sometimes called a glass harp.
Instrument made of spinning glass disks or bowls played by touching with the fingers.
Tuned klaxon horns or car horns.
Alto kalimba. A modern interpretation of the traditional Shona mbira.
Kalimba (generic). A modern interpretation of the traditional Shona mbira.
Treble kalimba. A modern interpretation of the traditional Shona mbira.
Snare drum, also known as side drum.
Pair of twin hand drums used in Indian classical music.
Inverted metal bowls nested on a vertical rod in order of pitch. The pitches are indefinite.
Hi-hat. Combination of two cymbals and a pedal.
Chimes hung from a horizontal bar in order of pitch. The pitches are indefinite.
Temple blocks, sometimes known as Chinese temple blocks or wooden bells.
Dried donkey or horse jawbone, traditionally used as a rattle in some Latin American countries.
Ratchet, also known as a rattle.
Pair of blocks wrapped in sandpaper, played by rubbing together.
Large shaker in the form of a tube.
Two wooden boards joined by a hinge, played by being brought together rapidly. Also known as a slap stick.
General MIDI percussion kit with Level 2 extensions.
Counter tenor or male alto voice.
Hammond organ with Leslie rotary speaker.
New age synth pad (General MIDI program 89).
Electric guitar (notated with 8va bassa treble clef).
Electric guitar (notated with normal treble clef).
Acoustic steel-string guitar (staff notation, with 8va bassa treble clef).
Acoustic steel-string guitar (staff notation, with normal treble clef).
Acoustic nylon-string guitar (staff notation, with 8va bassa treble clef).
Acoustic nylon-string guitar (staff notation, with normal treble clef).
Guitar with a second, fretless neck with up to nine bass strings. Developed in Vienna in the mid-19th century.
5-string electric bass guitar, high C tuning (staff notation).
5-string electric bass guitar, high C tuning (tablature).
Tenor ukulele with bottom string tuned to G4.
Tenor ukulele with bottom string tuned to G3.
Larger ancestor of the mandolin. Tuned an octave lower than the mandolin.
Larger ancestor of the mandolin. Tuned an octave lower than the standard mandola.
Also known as the Appalachian dulcimer, among other names. A fretted string instrument of the zither family. (Staff notation).
Also known as the Appalachian dulcimer, among other names. A fretted string instrument of the zither family. (Tablature).
Larger version of the mountain or Appalachian dulcimer. (Staff notation).
Larger version of the mountain or Appalachian dulcimer. (Tablature).
Very large mountain or Appalachian dulcimer, an octave lower than the regular dulcimer. (Staff notation).
Very large mountain or Appalachian dulcimer, an octave lower than the regular dulcimer. (Tablature).
Piccolo balalaika, tuned a fifth above the prima.
Prima balalaika. The most common balalaika.
Prima balalaika. The most common balalaika.
Secunda balalaika, tuned a fifth below the prima.
Alto balalaika, tuned an octave below the prima.
Bass balalaika, tuned an octave below the alto.
Contrabass balalaika, tuned an octave below the bass.
Short-neck lute-type fretless stringed instrument, common in the Middle East and North Africa.
Traditional Japanese three-stringed instrument played with a plectrum.
Plucked string instrument used in Indian classical music.
The smallest tamburica, mostly used as a lead instrument.
A larger tamburica than the prim, played in a similar way.
A tamburica mostly used as a harmony/rhythm instrument.
The largest tamburica, used for playing bass lines.
A tamburica similar in size to the bugarija, usually given counterpoint lines.
Spanish folk instrument similar to the mandolin. (Staff notation).
Spanish folk instrument similar to the mandolin. (Tablature).
Spanish lute similar to the bandurria. (Staff notation).
Spanish lute similar to the bandurria. (Tablature).
String section notated on a grand staff.
Treble viola da gamba. Second highest member of the viol family.
Alto viola da gamba. Third highest member of the viol family.
Highest-pitched member of the viol family.
Tenor viola da gamba. Middle member of the viol family.
Similar to the viol, but with an extra set of plucked strings.
Bass viola da gamba (staff notation). Third lowest member of the viol family.
Bass viola da gamba (tablature). Third lowest member of the viol family.
Large viol with the lowest string tuned to G. Sometimes called the G violone or great bass viol. Second lowest member of the viol family.
Large viol with the lowest string tuned to D. Sometimes called the D violone or contrabass viol. Lowest-pitched member of the viol family.
Extremely large and rare bowed string instrument, essentially a larger version of the double bass.
Swedish bowed instrument with keys to change the pitch of the strings.
